elements.content: A trifluoromethyl functionalized linker and Cu-O chain composed MOF, LIFM-100, was used as “crystalline sponge” to determine eight hardly crystallized liquids’ configurations based on its flexibility conformation, suitable pore size, electron-rich channel environment, and low symmetric space group. The H bond interactions between host–guest and guest–guest were well analyzed.
elements.clean_text: A trifluoromethyl functionalized linker and Cu-O chain composed MOF, LIFM-100, was used as "crystalline sponge" to determine eight hardly crystallized liquids' configurations based on its flexibility conformation, suitable pore size, electron-rich channel environment, and low symmetric space group. The H bond interactions between host-guest and guest-guest were well analyzed.

elements.content: We used trifluoromethyl ligand to synthesize a low symmetric, flexible Cu-MOF, with suitable pore size and high electron-density channels, as a “crystalline sponge” for guests determination, and the interactions such as H bond were analyzed specifically.
elements.clean_text: We used trifluoromethyl ligand to synthesize a low symmetric, flexible Cu-MOF, with suitable pore size and high electron-density channels, as a "crystalline sponge" for guests determination, and the interactions such as H bond were analyzed specifically.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) is commonly taken for one of the most effective and reliable methods for structure determination. However, there is one severe bottleneck accompanied by the technique that the target material must be single crystal in principle. Thus, a great number of molecules, such as substances with low melting point, amorphous molecules, and some natural product, are not applicable to this method owing to their difficult crystallization, while the exact configurations of these compounds are significant when they are applied to relative fields, such as drug discovery, visualization of chemical reaction, observation of transient intermediates, and so on. Recently, Fujita and colleagues developed an innovative strategy that overcomes the above disadvantage, termed as the “crystalline sponge” method. With this technology, the structure of a hardly crystallized target guest can be clearly determined by virtue of the host framework. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of porous material with periodic alignment, are constructed from various of metal ions (or metal clusters) and organic ligands. Because of their permanent porosity, tunable functionalities, crystalline nature, and high BET surface area, they have exhibited a variety of potential applications in different domains, such as gas adsorption and separation, fluorescent sensor, catalysis, guest determination, etc. Meantime, by artificially adjusting MOFs structures, like their space groups, pore size, functional group of linkers, and so on, some MOFs can be ideal candidates for “crystalline sponge”.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) is commonly taken for one of the most effective and reliable methods for structure determination. However, there is one severe bottleneck accompanied by the technique that the target material must be single crystal in principle. Thus, a great number of molecules, such as substances with low melting point, amorphous molecules, and some natural product, are not applicable to this method owing to their difficult crystallization, while the exact configurations of these compounds are significant when they are applied to relative fields, such as drug discovery, visualization of chemical reaction, observation of transient intermediates, and so on. Recently, Fujita and colleagues developed an innovative strategy that overcomes the above disadvantage, termed as the "crystalline sponge" method. With this technology, the structure of a hardly crystallized target guest can be clearly determined by virtue of the host framework. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of porous material with periodic alignment, are constructed from various of metal ions (or metal clusters) and organic ligands. Because of their permanent porosity, tunable functionalities, crystalline nature, and high BET surface area, they have exhibited a variety of potential applications in different domains, such as gas adsorption and separation, fluorescent sensor, catalysis, guest determination, etc. Meantime, by artificially adjusting MOFs structures, like their space groups, pore size, functional group of linkers, and so on, some MOFs can be ideal candidates for "crystalline sponge".

elements.content: Here, we report a Cu-MOF, named LIFM-100 (LIFM stands for Lehn Institute of Functional Materials), constructed from Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O and fluorinated ligand L (2,2′-bis­(trifluoromethyl)-4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, SI, Scheme S1). Its four characteristics are noteworthy: (1) LIFM-100 possessed a relatively low symmetry, which was anisotropic enough to render guest molecules orderly. On the contrary, in a highly symmetric framework, guest molecules are apt to be disordered. (2) Ls and Cu-O chains formed one type of 9 Å diameter double-wall tetragonal channel for guests absorption. (3) The special double-wall channel enabled the resultant framework to bear a certain extent flexibility to accommodate diverse guests. (4) The specifically introduced trifluoromethyl of L generated a high electron density channel environment, which increased affinity to electron-deficient guest molecules. In addition, the proper pore size and strong affinity channels of LIFM-100 may make the guests diffuse slowly into the voids of the host, which is supposed to be crucial to render the guests thermodynamically well equilibrated at the corresponding molecular-recognition sites of the “crystalline sponge”. As a result, LIFM-100 should be an appropriate matrix for “crystalline sponge”.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report a Cu-MOF, named LIFM-100 (LIFM stands for Lehn Institute of Functional Materials), constructed from Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O and fluorinated ligand L (2,2'-bis(trifluoromethyl)-4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, SI, Scheme S1). Its four characteristics are noteworthy: (1) LIFM-100 possessed a relatively low symmetry, which was anisotropic enough to render guest molecules orderly. On the contrary, in a highly symmetric framework, guest molecules are apt to be disordered. (2) Ls and Cu-O chains formed one type of 9 Å diameter double-wall tetragonal channel for guests absorption. (3) The special double-wall channel enabled the resultant framework to bear a certain extent flexibility to accommodate diverse guests. (4) The specifically introduced trifluoromethyl of L generated a high electron density channel environment, which increased affinity to electron-deficient guest molecules. In addition, the proper pore size and strong affinity channels of LIFM-100 may make the guests diffuse slowly into the voids of the host, which is supposed to be crucial to render the guests thermodynamically well equilibrated at the corresponding molecular-recognition sites of the "crystalline sponge". As a result, LIFM-100 should be an appropriate matrix for "crystalline sponge".

elements.content: The reaction of Cu­(NO3)·2.5H2O and L in the DMAC/H2O system yields [Cu6O4L4]·4DMAC (LIFM-100) as blue block crystals. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that LIFM-100 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c (SI, Table S1). They are one type of rarely reported Cu-O chain that consists of three types of Cu centers and two types of carboxylate group and one type of μ3-OH (c). Cu1/Cu1A coordinated with 5 O atoms, has trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Three O atoms of equatorial plane are from three carboxylate groups, with the distance range of 1.98–2.27 Å. Meanwhile, the two O atoms of axial positions belong to μ3-OHs, with the distances of 1.93 and 1.95 Å, respectively. Cu2/Cu2A and Cu3/Cu3A all possess square planar geometry formed with two μ3-OH and two carboxylates. Two of them are from the same two μ3-OHs, with the distances of 1.93 and 2.02 Å, and 1.94 and 2.02 Å and the rest 2 O atoms that come from different Ls, with a distance range of 1.90–1.96 Å. Especially, one of the carboxylate of Cu2/Cu2A coordinate with the metal center by only one O atoms. There are two types of Ls in the MOF, half of them coordinated to four Cu centers with four O atoms from two carboxylate groups, while the others are coordinated to three Cu centers with O atoms from two carboxylate groups. Ls and Cu-O chains formed one type of double-wall tetragonal channel with 9 Å diameter and an F-atom decorated surface (a, and SI, Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: The reaction of Cu(NO3)⋅2.5H2O and L in the DMAC/H2O system yields [Cu6O4L4]⋅4DMAC (LIFM-100) as blue block crystals. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that LIFM-100 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c (SI, Table S1). They are one type of rarely reported Cu-O chain that consists of three types of Cu centers and two types of carboxylate group and one type of μ3-OH (c). Cu1/Cu1A coordinated with 5 O atoms, has trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Three O atoms of equatorial plane are from three carboxylate groups, with the distance range of 1.98-2.27 Å. Meanwhile, the two O atoms of axial positions belong to μ3-OHs, with the distances of 1.93 and 1.95 Å, respectively. Cu2/Cu2A and Cu3/Cu3A all possess square planar geometry formed with two μ3-OH and two carboxylates. Two of them are from the same two μ3-OHs, with the distances of 1.93 and 2.02 Å, and 1.94 and 2.02 Å and the rest 2 O atoms that come from different Ls, with a distance range of 1.90-1.96 Å. Especially, one of the carboxylate of Cu2/Cu2A coordinate with the metal center by only one O atoms. There are two types of Ls in the MOF, half of them coordinated to four Cu centers with four O atoms from two carboxylate groups, while the others are coordinated to three Cu centers with O atoms from two carboxylate groups. Ls and Cu-O chains formed one type of double-wall tetragonal channel with 9 Å diameter and an F-atom decorated surface (a, and SI, Figure S1).

elements.content: (a) Structure of LIFM-100. (b) Cu-O chain of LIFM-100. (c) Coordination geometries of Cu centers.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structure of LIFM-100. (b) Cu-O chain of LIFM-100. (c) Coordination geometries of Cu centers.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of as-synthesized LIFM-100 matches well with its simulation, confirming the purity and the good crystallinity of LIFM-100, meanwhile showing that LIFM-100 met the prerequisites as a “crystalline sponge” (SI, Figure S10). Combined with above features, such as a low symmetric group, suitable pore size, frame flexibility, and electron-rich channel environment, LIFM-100 could be applied as specimen for crystallographic study of chemically related simple guests’ detailed configurations. We chose eight hardly crystallized liquids (DMAC (ingredient), DMF, DEF, ethanol, propanol, butanol, pentanol, sec-pentanol), which require rather low temperature to crystallize as target guests to testify to our conjecture. The long sides of guests dimensions are around 1/3 to 1/2 of the channel size (SI, Table S9), which means LIFM-100 can easily accommodate these guests. We immersed the LIFM-100 crystals in the above solvents separately for 12 h, except DMAC, then we obtained seven crystals (LIFM-100-DMF, LIFM-100-DEF, LIFM-100-ethanol, LIFM-100-propanol, LIFM-100-butanol, LIFM-100-pentanol, LIFM-100-s-pentaonl) through the process (SI, section S2.2 and S3) on a single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) manner and profited from the malleability of the framework.
elements.clean_text: The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of as-synthesized LIFM-100 matches well with its simulation, confirming the purity and the good crystallinity of LIFM-100, meanwhile showing that LIFM-100 met the prerequisites as a "crystalline sponge" (SI, Figure S10). Combined with above features, such as a low symmetric group, suitable pore size, frame flexibility, and electron-rich channel environment, LIFM-100 could be applied as specimen for crystallographic study of chemically related simple guests' detailed configurations. We chose eight hardly crystallized liquids (DMAC (ingredient), DMF, DEF, ethanol, propanol, butanol, pentanol, sec-pentanol), which require rather low temperature to crystallize as target guests to testify to our conjecture. The long sides of guests dimensions are around 1/3 to 1/2 of the channel size (SI, Table S9), which means LIFM-100 can easily accommodate these guests. We immersed the LIFM-100 crystals in the above solvents separately for 12 h, except DMAC, then we obtained seven crystals (LIFM-100-DMF, LIFM-100-DEF, LIFM-100-ethanol, LIFM-100-propanol, LIFM-100-butanol, LIFM-100-pentanol, LIFM-100-s-pentaonl) through the process (SI, section S2.2 and S3) on a single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) manner and profited from the malleability of the framework.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrates that all crystals remain in P21/c space group and similar architectures, while the cell parameters vary depending on different guests absorbed in the ductile double-wall channels (SI, Table S1–S8). Meanwhile, due to the guest exchange causing slip of the crystals, LIFM-100 guests’ cell volumes decreased to half of LIFM-100s, and another significant change is that the cell parameter β ranged from 95.5° to 106.5°, owing to the flexibility of frame to accommodate the absorbed guests. All the H bond interactions of host–guest and guest–guest were calculated by the PLATON program and listed in , and the specific details are clearly depicted in SI, Figure S9. Guest distributions and configurations are clearly exhibited in SI, Table S9.
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrates that all crystals remain in P21/c space group and similar architectures, while the cell parameters vary depending on different guests absorbed in the ductile double-wall channels (SI, Table S1-S8). Meanwhile, due to the guest exchange causing slip of the crystals, LIFM-100 guests' cell volumes decreased to half of LIFM-100s, and another significant change is that the cell parameter β ranged from 95.5° to 106.5°, owing to the flexibility of frame to accommodate the absorbed guests. All the H bond interactions of host-guest and guest-guest were calculated by the PLATON program and listed in , and the specific details are clearly depicted in SI, Figure S9. Guest distributions and configurations are clearly exhibited in SI, Table S9.

</table-wrap>

Take LIFM-100 as an instance. There are fpir DMAC molecules in an asymmetric unit, and each molecule has interactions with the framework (). Molecule M-A has a H bond with an O atom from L (H74B···O11 = 2.556 Å), H72A from M-C also has a H bond with a O10 atom from the Cu–O chain, and the bond length is 2.428 Å, respectively. Besides, H66C from M-B and H78C from M-D have H bond interactions with F9, F10, and F11 and run the lengths of 2.548, 2.522 and 2.583 Å, respectively. These interactions between host and guest guide the DMAC molecules by taking the specific positions in the channels and make the corresponding configurations be well-defined. As and SI, Figure S9, show, the main block of the interactions of host–guest and guest–guest are H bond interactions between host and guest coming from the introduced trifluoromethyl group and H-bond receptor O atoms from Cu–O chain. Meantime, mutual effects between guest and guest, especially in LIFM-100-ethanol and butanol, play a crucial part in some molecules’ configurations. Other weaker and longer range interactions that are not visualized, such as van der Waals, should also contribute to the specific configurations and occupations of the guests. Furthermore, it is worth noting that all guests’ polar ends take the position near the Cu–O chain, and the nonpolar ends extend toward the centers of the channels. This may be on account of the strong polarity of the Cu–O chain, which possesses affinity to guests’ polar ends yet rejects guests’ nonpolar ends, while the low polarity channels have affinity to guests’ nonpolar ends.
elements.clean_text: Take LIFM-100 as an instance. There are fpir DMAC molecules in an asymmetric unit, and each molecule has interactions with the framework (). Molecule M-A has a H bond with an O atom from L (H74B⋅⋅⋅O11 = 2.556 Å), H72A from M-C also has a H bond with a O10 atom from the Cu-O chain, and the bond length is 2.428 Å, respectively. Besides, H66C from M-B and H78C from M-D have H bond interactions with F9, F10, and F11 and run the lengths of 2.548, 2.522 and 2.583 Å, respectively. These interactions between host and guest guide the DMAC molecules by taking the specific positions in the channels and make the corresponding configurations be well-defined. As  and SI, Figure S9, show, the main block of the interactions of host-guest and guest-guest are H bond interactions between host and guest coming from the introduced trifluoromethyl group and H-bond receptor O atoms from Cu-O chain. Meantime, mutual effects between guest and guest, especially in LIFM-100-ethanol and butanol, play a crucial part in some molecules' configurations. Other weaker and longer range interactions that are not visualized, such as van der Waals, should also contribute to the specific configurations and occupations of the guests. Furthermore, it is worth noting that all guests' polar ends take the position near the Cu-O chain, and the nonpolar ends extend toward the centers of the channels. This may be on account of the strong polarity of the Cu-O chain, which possesses affinity to guests' polar ends yet rejects guests' nonpolar ends, while the low polarity channels have affinity to guests' nonpolar ends.

elements.content: Guest distributions, configurations, and interactions with host in one asymmetric unit of LIFM-100.
elements.clean_text: 2  Guest distributions, configurations, and interactions with host in one asymmetric unit of LIFM-100.

elements.content: Notably, these liquid guests possess a relatively low melting point for crystallization, which makes their exact configurations hard to be analyzed via SCXRD. However, we successfully synthesized a flexible “crystalline sponge”, LIFM-100, to help arrange disordered liquid molecules into a highly ordered state in the channels of LIFM-100 that benefitted from its characteristics. Through X-ray crystallography, guests’ detailed structures are clearly elucidated. LIFM-100 as a new family member of “crystalline sponge” can be regarded as an ideal candidate for certain liquid determinations.
elements.clean_text: Notably, these liquid guests possess a relatively low melting point for crystallization, which makes their exact configurations hard to be analyzed via SCXRD. However, we successfully synthesized a flexible "crystalline sponge", LIFM-100, to help arrange disordered liquid molecules into a highly ordered state in the channels of LIFM-100 that benefitted from its characteristics. Through X-ray crystallography, guests' detailed structures are clearly elucidated. LIFM-100 as a new family member of "crystalline sponge" can be regarded as an ideal candidate for certain liquid determinations.

elements.content: In conclusion, we successfully demonstrate that LIFM-100 can act as an excellent crystalline sponge for adsorbing and help determining eight liquids’ configurations. By introducing the hardly crystallized organic liquid molecules into LIFM-100, they took up specific sites and distributed orderly in the channels of the “crystalline sponge”. Overall, the orientations and occupations of eight guests exhibited marvelous similarity, which should be attributed to the polarities of Cu–O chain and the channels. Moreover, the explicit configurations of guests were mainly ascribed to the host–guest and guest–guest interactions, such as H bond interactions and van der Waals interactions. With the details of the interactions in , the mechanism of how the guests were rendered regularly ordered was eligible. On the other hand, the satisfactory results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction verified that the low symmetric space group, flexible conformation, high electron density channel environment ornamented by a functionalized trifluoromethyl group, and suitable pore size of LIFM-100 were effective features to facilitate the determination of guests via “crystalline sponge”. We believe LIFM-100 has potential to determine a greater variety of guests, and our future work can refer to the consequences of LIFM-100 and optimize new sponges based on their symmetry, flexibility, pore environment, and pore size.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we successfully demonstrate that LIFM-100 can act as an excellent crystalline sponge for adsorbing and help determining eight liquids' configurations. By introducing the hardly crystallized organic liquid molecules into LIFM-100, they took up specific sites and distributed orderly in the channels of the "crystalline sponge". Overall, the orientations and occupations of eight guests exhibited marvelous similarity, which should be attributed to the polarities of Cu-O chain and the channels. Moreover, the explicit configurations of guests were mainly ascribed to the host-guest and guest-guest interactions, such as H bond interactions and van der Waals interactions. With the details of the interactions in , the mechanism of how the guests were rendered regularly ordered was eligible. On the other hand, the satisfactory results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction verified that the low symmetric space group, flexible conformation, high electron density channel environment ornamented by a functionalized trifluoromethyl group, and suitable pore size of LIFM-100 were effective features to facilitate the determination of guests via "crystalline sponge". We believe LIFM-100 has potential to determine a greater variety of guests, and our future work can refer to the consequences of LIFM-100 and optimize new sponges based on their symmetry, flexibility, pore environment, and pore size.

metadata.title: A Flexible Cu-MOF as Crystalline Sponge for Guests Determination
